General course objectives:
General course objectives
The goal is to provide insight into the physics of atmospheric plasmas. The focus will be on electric discharge plasmas and associated phenomena. The student will acquire basic knowledge of the microphysics of discharges, the inception and properties of discharges in various gas mixtures, transient luminous events (TLEs) and terrestrial gamma-ray flashes (TGFs). The acquired knowledge forms the foundation for further studies of electric discharges, both theoretically and through space data.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
define the steps in discharge evolution
classify the relation between streamers, leaders, transient luminous events and terrestrial gamma-ray flashes
explain and calculate the electron motion in various gas mixtures
calculate collision probabilities of particles moving in an ambient gas
plan and design simulations of particle swarms in an ambient gas
analyze and interpret space-data with respect to discharge properties
use and exploit well-known theoretical and empirical models for the atmospheric plasmas.
explain the structure of the atmosphere
Content: Particle motion in collision-dominated plasmas; structure of the atmosphere; streamers; leaders; transient luminous events; terrestrial gamma-ray flashes; simulations; data analysis; various gas mixtures.
